security: The letter reveals the CIA's use of State Department cover to enable officers to work overseas and maintain relationships with allied liaison services. "Effective official cover is necessary to enable our officers to work overseas in often hostile and volatile environments... State Department cover is critically important because its use affords our officers the rights and privileges set forth in the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic and Consular Immunity--diplomatic immunity, in particular." Disclosing this information could compromise the security of CIA officers and their operations.
summary: David W. Carey, Executive Director of the CIA, urges the Assassination Records Review Board to reconsider its decision to release documents that would reveal the Agency's use of State Department cover, arguing that it is essential for operational utility and personal security.
summary_one_paragraph: In a letter dated September 26, 1997, CIA Executive Director David W. Carey appeals to Judge John Raymond Tunheim, Chairman of the Assassination Records Review Board, to reconsider the release of documents exposing the CIA's use of State Department cover. Carey emphasizes that this cover is critical for CIA officers' security and operational effectiveness overseas, enabling them to work in hostile environments and maintain relationships with allied liaison services. He contends that revealing this practice would increase risks for both CIA officers and State Department colleagues, and he offers a senior CIA representative to further explain the Agency's concerns and provide a more comprehensive memorandum on the damage issue.
title: Letter Regarding Release of Documents Revealing CIA's Use of State Department Cover
sender: David W. Carey, Executive Director of the CIA
